data.data:
[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-24] Somar Meteorologia reported Minas Gerais received 62.8 mm of rain (138% of historical average). [2026-02-25] AccuWeather forecasts clearing trend starting Feb 28. [2026-02-06] Conab projects record 66.2 million bag harvest (+17.2% YoY).
[ANALYSIS]: Somar Meteorologia data indicating 138% of historical rainfall in Minas Gerais confirms optimal soil moisture during the critical bean-filling stage, directly supporting Conab's projection of a record 66.2 million bag harvest (+17.2% YoY). The transition to a clearing trend predicted by AccuWeather for late February is technically ideal, allowing for bean maturation without the fungal risks associated with continuous dampness. By dispelling earlier dry condition concerns, the weather data solidifies the fundamental supply glut narrative, justifying a bearish price outlook.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-25] USD/BRL exchange rate is ~5.1550, with the Real strengthening 2.39% over the past month and 11.18% over the last 12 months (Trading Economics). [2026-02-09] Farmer sales for the 2025/26 soybean crop are 34-38%, lagging the historical average by ~10pp explicitly due to the 'stronger Real' and low prices (Agrolatam). [2026-02-23] The Central Bank of Brazil held the Selic rate at 15.00%, a restrictive level that continues to support the currency (Investing.com / BCB).
[ANALYSIS]: The previous analysis correctly identified the currency mechanism but failed to align the sentiment with the supply-side implications. The data indicates a structural tightening of Brazilian supply driven by the Real's appreciation (+11.18% YoY) and a restrictive 15.00% Selic rate. The 10pp lag in soybean sales serves as a high-confidence proxy for the broader agricultural sector, including Coffee; as the BRL strengthens, farmers withhold inventory because they receive fewer Reais per USD sold. This effectively raises the USD-denominated floor price for Arabica. Consequently, the currency environment is not merely neutral but actively restricts export flow, providing bullish support for USD-quoted coffee futures.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-19] Port of Santos handled a record 12.7 million tonnes in Jan 2026, though Cecafé warns this figure 'masks' persistent bottlenecks for containerized coffee. (source: DatamarNews); [2026-02-19] CMA CGM announced a reversion of Asia-Europe services to the Cape of Good Hope route due to security risks, cementing 10-14 day transit delays. (source: S&P Global); [2026-02-25] Severe congestion at the Port of Mombasa is threatening East African coffee exports, forcing some exporters to utilize air freight at 8x the cost. (source: The EastAfrican); [2026-02-25] The EUDR enforcement deadline is officially confirmed as delayed to December 30, 2026. (source: ResourceWise)
[ANALYSIS]: The previous assessment flawed the interpretation of Brazilian data by conflating record 'total' throughput with efficient 'coffee' flow; high bulk volume at Santos typically crowds out containerized cargo, validating Cecafé's warning of bottlenecks rather than disproving it. Correcting for this, the physical supply chain is showing synchronized stress: Brazil (container competition), East Africa (Mombasa congestion forcing expensive air freight), and global transit (CMA CGM reverting to longer Cape routes). Under normal circumstances, this logistical tightening would be bullish. However, the confirmed EUDR delay removes the critical 'demand pull' catalyst. Without the immediate regulatory deadline forcing buyers to rush inventory despite these logistical hurdles, the market enters a high-cost, high-friction stasis rather than a rally.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-20] Global port congestion reached a three-month high, with 10.5% of the global fleet (3.3 million TEU) currently stuck in bottlenecks (Source: Metro Global). [2026-02-12] Cecafé confirmed January 2026 green coffee exports fell 30.74% year-on-year to 2.53 million bags, citing tighter carryover stocks and infrastructure issues (Source: CocoaIntel / Cecafé). Raw Research Findings indicate the Port of Santos infrastructure is 'exhausted,' causing significant losses for exporters despite a 14-20% decline in global freight rates (Source: MarketScreener / Trading Economics). [2026-02-23] The Drewry World Container Index fell 1% to $1,919 per 40ft container, marking the sixth consecutive weekly decline (Source: TrasportoEuropa / Drewry).
[ANALYSIS]: The previous analysis correctly identified the bullish implications of the bottleneck but erroneously referenced a 'bearish long-term crop outlook' which was not present in the provided evidence; in fact, the evidence cites 'tighter carryover stocks,' which reinforces the bullish case. The revised assessment focuses on the critical disconnect between pricing and availability: while logistics costs are falling (Drewry Index down 1% to $1,919; global rates down 14-20%), physical throughput is failing. The 30.74% drop in exports reported by Cecafé, combined with 'exhausted' infrastructure at Santos and 10.5% of the global fleet stuck in congestion, confirms a supply shock. The inability to move product despite lower shipping costs creates immediate scarcity, justifying a bullish sentiment.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ICE Arabica certified stocks reported at 453,612 bags on Feb 24, 2026, with pending grading stocks rising to 171,080 bags (StoneX / MacroMicro). Brazil's Conab projects a record 2026 coffee crop of 66.2 million bags, a 17.2% year-on-year increase (Barchart / Conab). Global green bean exports for December 2025 rose 9.2% year-on-year to 10.15 million bags (GCR Magazine / ICO). The Arabica futures curve remains in backwardation, with a March-December spread of approximately -10.95 cents (CocoaIntel).
[ANALYSIS]: The market structure presents a classic conflict between immediate spot tightness and a looming supply deluge, but the weight of evidence favors a BEARISH trajectory. While the backwardation of -10.95 cents confirms current commercial demand for immediate delivery, this tightness is likely the peak of the cycle. The critical leading indicator is the surge in pending grading stocks to 171,080 bags; this volume represents a massive imminent injection into certified inventory that will likely crush the backwardation structure. Furthermore, the fundamental backdrop has shifted decisively with Conab's projection of a record 66.2 million bag crop (+17.2% YoY) and a 9.2% rise in global exports. The market is transitioning from a deficit-driven rally to a surplus-driven correction, making the current price levels unsustainable against the incoming physical supply.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: 1. StoneX reported that the February 20 COT report showed managed money reduced their net long positions by 1,336 lots to a total of 2,220 net lots long as of February 17. (source: StoneX); 2. Nasdaq and Barchart reported that coffee prices recovered from a 7.25-month low as technical short-covering emerged from 'deeply oversold territory.' (source: Nasdaq/Barchart); 3. Arabica coffee futures (May 26) showed resistance at 285.50, with traders awaiting a retest of the previous week's low at 275.65, which could trigger further downside toward 261/265. (source: StoneX); 4. ADM Investor Services reported that May Coffee broke below a five-month consolidation in late January and is now consolidating in a range established in July 2025, with Brazil's 2026 crop forecast at a record 44.1 to 48.0 million bags for arabica. (source: ADM Investor Services); 5. Non-commercial net positions for Coffee C were reported with a COT Index value of 25,476, reflecting a bearish shift in sentiment compared to previous months. (source: MacroMicro)
[ANALYSIS]: Critique: 1. No major logical fallacies; the analysis avoids confirmation bias by acknowledging short-covering as a counterpoint to bearish pressures, though it slightly emphasizes supply factors without exploring demand drivers (e.g., no mention of consumption trends). Recency bias is minimal, as it integrates recent COT data with forward-looking crop forecasts. False causation is present in loosely linking reduced net longs directly to 'excess supply perceptions' without explicit evidence of demand weakness. 2. All claims are tied to specific sources (StoneX, Nasdaq/Barchart, ADM, MacroMicro), with no vague assertions. 3. The bearish sentiment tag is justified by evidence of position reductions, downside price targets, and record supply forecasts, though short-covering introduces mild bullish nuance, supporting an overall bearish but not extreme view. Revised Analysis: The decline in managed money net long positions to 2,220 lots per StoneX's COT data signals reduced speculative bullishness, likely influenced by Brazil's projected record arabica crop of 44.1-48.0 million bags (ADM Investor Services), pointing to potential supply overhang. While Nasdaq/Barchart note short-covering from oversold levels aiding a price recovery, StoneX highlights resistance at 285.50 and risks of further declines to 261/265 if support at 275.65 breaks. The bearish COT Index shift to 25,476 (MacroMicro) reinforces sentiment deterioration, though consolidation patterns suggest near-term range-bound trading unless demand indicators improve.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-25] Arabica coffee futures rose to 285.89 USd/Lbs, up 0.59% from the previous day, recovering from a 15-month low of 275.27. (source: Trading Economics); [2026-02-25] The 200-day Simple Moving Average (SMA) for US Coffee C Futures is explicitly recorded at 318.00. (source: Investing.com); [2026-02-24] Technical indicators show a bullish RSI and Stochastic divergence as prices test the 280 support zone despite a broader bearish trend. (source: TradingView); [2026-02-05] Brazil's Conab agency forecasts a record 2026 coffee production of 66.2 million bags, a 17.2% year-over-year increase. (source: Barchart); Support levels are identified at 280.00 and 275.27, while major resistance is found at the 200-day SMA of 318.00 and the 52-week high of 340.30 for the KCH7 contract. (source: Raw Research Findings)
[ANALYSIS]: The current price of 285.89 USd/Lbs is below the 200-day SMA of 318.00, confirming a bearish long-term structure with lower highs and lows, driven by Brazil's forecasted record production of 66.2 million bags, which suggests supply growth of 17.2% could outstrip demand and exert downward pressure. Recent recovery from the 15-month low of 275.27, with support holding at 280.00, coincides with bullish RSI and Stochastic divergences indicating potential short-term oversold conditions and a possible bounce. However, without a confirmed moving average crossover or demand-side catalysts (e.g., weather disruptions or consumption upticks), the oversupply outlook dominates, limiting upside beyond resistance at 318.00. This balances short-term technical resilience against fundamental bearish forces.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-25] KCK26 trading at 285.50, near 52-week low of 275.35; [2026-02-25] Research notes option premiums are 'expensive' vs historical realized volatility; [2026-02-24] Rebound from 15-month low driven by short-covering and stronger Real; [2026-02-20] IV for KCZ27 is 30.68%.
[ANALYSIS]: The market presents a classic conflict between bearish fundamentals (record crop forecasts) and bullish technical extremes (oversold conditions at 15-month lows). The previous analysis correctly identified the High Volatility regime but failed to adequately weigh the risk of the 'record crop' fundamental data, which could invalidate the support level. However, the critical edge lies in the volatility pricing: evidence explicitly states option premiums are 'expensive' relative to realized volatility. This pricing anomaly favors selling premium over directional speculation. While the trend is bearish, the short-covering bounce off the 275.35 support suggests the market is overextended to the downside. Therefore, a neutral-to-bullish credit strategy is statistically superior to buying the dip outright. The revised view maintains the Bull Put Spread recommendation but clarifies it as a volatility-arbitrage play (capturing rich premiums) rather than a fundamental bullish call.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

data.title: How many Fed rate cuts in 2026?
How much revenue will the U.S. raise from tariffs in 2025?

data.reason: Fed Policy Shock: HAWKISH_PIVOT - FOMC Minutes released May 22 revealed that many officials questioned whether current interest rates were restrictive enough to cool inflation, with some participants expressing a willingness to tighten policy further if risks to inflation materialize.

payload.summary: FOMC Minutes released May 22 revealed that many officials questioned whether current interest rates were restrictive enough to cool inflation, with some participants expressing a willingness to tighten policy further if risks to inflation materialize.
payload.market_impact: Positive for USD; Negative for Gold and commodities as the 'higher-for-longer' narrative gains traction and rate cut expectations are pushed back.
